thread.title: Tube strike January 2017: London begins to grind to halt as 24-hour crippling TfL walkout begins
thread.title_full: Tube strike January 2017: London begins to grind to halt as 24-hour crippling TfL walkout begins

author: Francesca Gillett
title: Tube strike January 2017: London begins to grind to halt as 24-hour crippling TfL walkout begins
text:
Sunday 8 January 2017 18:15 BST Strike: The walkout began at 6pm on Sunday evening. AFP/Getty Images 
London’s Tube network began to grind to a halt on Sunday evening at the start of a 24-hour strike set to cripple the city’s transport network. 
Up to 4,000 station and ticket office workers walked out in a bitter dispute over job losses and ticket closures after last-ditch weekend peace talks between transport bosses and unions collapsed. 
The strike began at 6pm on Sunday as some Zone 1 Tube stations prepared to close and major disruption across the rest of the network began. 
Many Londoners dashed to catch the last services before 6pm while others told how they were preparing their bikes for the morning commute on Monday. Zone 1: A sign at Leicester Square station. (AFP/Getty Images) 
Tube services will begin later on Monday, from 7am, and stations that do open are expected to close earlier at 7pm. 
Transport for London have not yet released details of which stations will be closed, but said nearly all Zone 1 stations will be shut during the walkout. 
There will be no Tube interchange from stations including Paddington, Victoria, King's Cross, Waterloo, Euston, Bank and London Bridge – although National Rail services are unaffected. All day Monday: The strike is set to last until the end of Monday. (AFP/Getty Images) 
Piccadilly line services will run between Hammersmith and Heathrow Terminals 1, 2 and 3, but there will be no service to Terminals 4 or 5. 
There will be no service at all on the Victoria or Waterloo & City lines, and all other lines will be severely affected with limited services in outer London. What time does the Tube strike start and when will it finish? 
TfL said they are putting on around 150 extra buses to move people about the city on Monday, while river services will also be enhanced. 
There will be posters, digital boards and announcements in stations to keep people informed of the latest level of service and people are advised to check before they travel at 
The dispute, led by RMT union and the TSSA, is over job cuts and ticket office closures by former London mayor Boris Johnson. 
TfL say there is “no need for a strike” and they have already started to recruit more staff. 
Bike specialist Halfords said they are offering free bike checks at its shops across the capital to help anyone switching to two wheels because of the Tube strike. 
The retail giant said its staff will check brakes, gears, wheels, tyres and chains and offer expert advice on bike maintenance and cycling. More about:
